dublinCore.dc:title: 117 HR 7781 IH: Urgently Feeding America’s Babies Act of 2022

action.action-desc: Mr. Buchanan introduced the following bill; which was referred to the Committee on Energy and Commerce, and in addition to the Committee on Financial Services, for a period to be subsequently determined by the Speaker, in each case for consideration of such provisions as fall within the jurisdiction of the committee concerned

form.official-title: To designate baby formula as a scarce and critical material under the Defense Production Act of 1950, and for other purposes.

section.text: This Act may be cited as the Urgently Feeding America’s Babies Act of 2022.

section.header: Designation of infant formula as critical material
section.text: Immediately upon the date of the enactment of this Act, the President shall determine under subsection (b) of section 101 of the Defense Production Act of 1950 (50 U.S.C. 4511) that—

paragraph.text: infant formula is scarce and a critical material essential to the national defense; and
the requirements of the national defense for infant formula cannot be met without exercising the authority provided by subsection (a) of that section.

section.header: Waiver by Food and Drug Administration

subsection.text: Not later than 15 days after the date of the enactment of this Act, the Secretary of Health and Human Services (referred to in this section as the Secretary) shall implement a process under which the Secretary may issue waivers, with respect to an infant formula that is available for commercial use in the European Union, of the requirements of sections 412 and 415 of the Federal Food, Drug, and Cosmetic Act (21 U.S.C. 350a; 350d), and other applicable requirements of such Act, as appropriate, in order to allow for the introduction into interstate commerce of such infant formula in the United States.
The Secretary shall publish safety guidelines for each infant formula for which a waiver is issued under this section.
